1. Overview

  The Zinus USA, Inc. (Zinus) facility located in McDonough (Henry County), GA will act as a production facility for foam mattresses. The facility will be located at an existing building located at 830 Highway 42 South, McDonough, Henry County, Georgia. 

 At the McDonough facility, chemicals arrive via truck and are stored on-site. Production for the site will start with memory foam mattresses, otherwise referred to as polyurethane foam or slab foam. The slab foam manufacturing takes place when ingredients are pumped into the slab foam machine. Combinations of methylene diphenyl diisocyante (MDI), toluene diisocyante (TDI), polyols (long chain) low vapor pressure alcohols, additives, catalysts, and a blowing agent are mixed in a dispensing head, then transferred to a laydown trough. The polyols used have very low vapor pressures (less than 0.1 mm Hg at 20 C), high molecular weights, and high boiling points of 300 F or greater. As a result of the chemical reaction and the low vapor pressures, the TDI components, polyols, and small quantities of catalysts become part of the produced foam.

  The trough is supported by a slab conveyor. The two compounds (TDI and MDI) have similar chemical structures and behaviors during the slab foam manufacturing process. It is expected that TDI will be used in about 70% of the production, and MDI the remaining 30%. As foam moves across the line, it expands due to a blowing agent and chemical reactions between TDI, polyols and catalyst. The foam is set in a five (5) ft wide by five (5) ft tall trough, which equates to about five (5) mattresses per slab. This is many times larger in volume than the initial volume of liquid mixture discharged from the mixing head. When the foam begins to rise it is soft, flexible, and initially quite hot from the reaction of the ingredients. 

  When the slab nears the end of the line it is cooler and rigid enough to be cut into "blocks" of foam about 6 to 8 ft long. Selected lengt

hs of the foam are cut, and those sections are transferred by fork truck to a nearby area to complete the setting process. When a foam block is "set", which is typically within 24 hours, it is stacked with other blocks to await further processing into practical lengths and thicknesses as needed for the mattresses being assembled.

  TDI will be stored in three (3) 50-ton tanks in the chemical storage building. The tanks have an inner diameter for 9.186 ft (2.8 meters), and a height of 22.474 ft (6.85 meters).

  The Risk Management Program (RMP) provisions apply to processes at Zinus USA Inc. as they involve a listed flammable or toxic chemical at or above the specified threshold quantities listed in 40 CFR 68.130. TDI (Toluene 2,4-diisocyanate [CAS # 584-84-9], Toluene 2,6-diisocyanate [CAS # 91-08-7], and Toluene diisocyanate [unspecified isomer, CAS # 26471-62-5]) is a regulated toxic chemical under 40 CFR 68.130 with a threshold quantity (TQ) of 10,000 lbs. TDI will be stored in quantities exceeding the TQ.  Zinus USA Inc.'s covered process is eligible for Program 2 requirements as it does not meet either of the requirements for Program 1 or Program 3 [40 CFR 68.10(c)]. 

2. Prevention of Accidental Releases

  In order to prevent accidental releases, the Zinus USA Inc. team underwent a robust RMP "what-if" analysis for receiving and the transfer of TDI at our onsite dock areas to our TDI storage vessels in the tank farm. After receiving the material, our analysis then examined the TDI transfer from our tank farm to our Laaderburg foaming machine.  Outcomes from this process identified the need for visual, routine and preventative maintenance checks, start-up/shut-down and operating procedures.  To mitigate the risk, Zinus USA Inc implemented procedures that provide expectations that cover receiving TDI from of our suppliers and expectations of the process of unloading TDI at Zinus USA Inc.  During the analysis of the overall transfer system process, we

have implemented a self-contained TDI unloading area with a distinct hose tie-in from our other unloading areas to prevent inadvertent mixing at the tank farm with a valve closure process at the unloading area that is done prior to filling to fully contain spilled TDI material. When loading the tank farm TDI vessels our operators receive real time information on aspects of filling level and pressure readings with the venting process at each vessel while a truck at the dock is unloading.  In the tank farm, the vessels are monitored and have automatic shut off systems in place to prevent overfill.  Calibrated leak detection is present at the top and bottom of all vessels to alert operators of any potential VOC IDLH conditions that may be present.

  Our "what-if" analysis extended to the transfer of TDI from the tank farm to the Laaderburg foaming machine.  Zinus USA Inc has also placed a calibrated leak detection device at the Laaderberg head where the chemicals in the process are mixed to provide forewarning in the event a malfunction occurs that could lead to a leak and subsequently an increase in VOC that would require evacuation. Outcomes from this process identified the need for visual, routine and preventative maintenance checks, start-up/shut-down and operating procedures.  In addition, Zinus USA Inc. will not only develop and continuously improve our existing aforementioned procedures, we continue our orientation and job specific training with current and future employees that cover actions taken in the event of an accidental release in the process. 

3. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

  The only RMP-listed toxic chemical and covered process that is present at the Zinus USA Inc. McDonough facility is TDI.  The term "process" is defined in §68.3 as:

... any activity involving a regulated substance including any use, storage, manufacturing, handling, or on-site movement of such substances, or combination of these activities.  For th

e purposes of this definition, any group of vessels that are interconnected, or separate vessels that are located such that a regulated substance could be involved in a potential release, shall be considered a single process.

The McDonough Facility TDI RMP covered process consists of the following areas:

¿  TDI Unloading - Offload liquid TDI from truck trailer into three TDI tanks (TDI Unloading Area)
¿  TDI Storage and Conditioning - Store and condition TDI in three TDI storage tanks (T2201-JA, T2201-JB, T2201-JC in Foam Bulk Storage Room).
¿  TDI Feed to Foaming Plant Mixer - deliver liquid TDI from TDI tanks to a Laaderberg MultiMax foaming plant.
¿  Foaming Plant Mixer Through Foaming Tunnel - produce flexible polyurethane foam from a reaction involving TDI, water, polyol, and additives, in the presence of a catalyst in the Laader Berg MultiMax foaming plant.

  The remaining areas of the McDonough facility (bulk unloading and storage in Foam Bulk Storage Room of other materials, foam block curing area, mattress warehouse), are not covered process areas. TDI is converted to polyurethane foam in the Laaderberg foaming plant because the foam mixture contains significantly more than a stoichiometric amount of polyol to react with all the TDI and catalyst when forming the polyurethane foam. Therefore, TDI is no longer present in significant concentration downstream of the foaming plant.

  The location of the TDI storage tanks was determined to be 33.418306° Latitude, -84.147639° Longitude (NAD 83: Zone 13N) using ArcGIS, converted to decimal degrees using http://www.rcn.montana.edu/Resources/Converter.aspx. This location was used in the MARPLOT software as the center point for the release radius.

4. General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

  When building a general accident release prevention program, Zinus USA Inc began with ensuring facility's Maintenance Inspection and Testing plan has specific informa

tion related to equipment manufacturer and model information and contains equipment specifications, such as material of construction (reference to the Maintenance Inspections and Testing Plan for equipment specification information [40 CFR 68.48(a)(4)]).  All systems and equipment are designed, fabricated, or installed in accordance with, at a minimum, the following codes and/or standards, as applicable [40 CFR 68.48(a)(5)]:

¿  American Concrete Institute (ACI)
¿  American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME), 1956 Code (Storage Tank)
¿  Occupational Safety and Health Act (OSHA)
¿  National Fire Protection Association (NFPA)
     ¿  NFPA 58 Liquefied Petroleum Gas Code
     ¿	NFPA 70 National Electrical Code
¿  Underwriters' Laboratories (UL)
¿  American Institute of Steel Construction (AISC)
¿  American Welding Society (AWS)
¿  International Building Code (IBC)

  To ensure and continuously improve a general accident release prevention program Zinus USA Inc underwent steps to conduct a review of the hazards associated with the regulated substances, process, and procedures. The review identified the following as applicable [40 CFR 68.50(a)]:

¿  The hazards associated with the process and regulated substances;
¿  Opportunities for equipment malfunctions or human errors that could cause an accidental release;
¿  The safeguards used or needed to control the hazards or prevent equipment malfunction or human error; and
¿  Any steps used or needed to detect or monitor releases.

  Zinus USA Inc has and continues to develop checklists where persons or organizations knowledgeable about the process and equipment were done as a guide to conducting the review. For processes designed to meet industry standards or Federal or state design rules, the hazard review shall, by inspecting all equipment, determine whether the process is designed, fabricated, and operated in accordance with the applicable standards or rules [40 CFR 68.50(b)]. Per 40 CFR 68.50(c),

ew or revision of training programs
¿  Topic and type of training provided (examples of training type include classroom, classroom plus on the job, on the job)
¿  Type of competency testing used (examples of testing type include verbal review, written exam, demonstration of job skills)

  Requirements applicable to the maintenance program that are relevant to the Accident Release Prevention Program are derived from equipment manufacturer recommendations, internal company standards, applicable regulations, and good engineering practice as defined by the body of applicable codes, standards, industry publications, and recommended practices. The Zinus USA Inc facility uses a spreadsheet system to manage the maintenance programs at it's facility. The system manages preventative maintenance for all physical assets.  

  Inspection and testing procedures may be written procedures specific to a given process equipment item or may apply to general categories of process equipment [40 CFR 68.56(a)]. Maintenance personnel are expected to possess the basic skill requirements and training associated with their craft specialty. Therefore, the inspection and testing procedures do not specify the particular craft skills (e.g., basic valve assembly/disassembly) unless such details are warranted due to equipment-specific or safety-related considerations. Each preventative maintenance activity required by the inspection and testing plan has an associated frequency at which the task needs be performed. Maintaining the inspection and testing procedures is the responsibility of the Maintenance Manager or their designee.  

  Equipment monitoring and evaluation is essential to reduce the likelihood of in-service equipment failure and, thus, maintain the mechanical integrity of the process. Regular equipment monitoring and evaluation can be achieved by developing a written inspection and testing procedures and establishing a schedule for testing and inspecting this equipment.

  G

ood engineering practices are defined in the applicable codes, standards, industry publications, and in-house engineering standards [40 CFR 68.56(d)]. In general, in-house engineering standards supplement the public domain references and should be applied on a case-by-case basis. Some of the more often used sources of good engineering practices include but are not limited to the following:

¿  American Institute of Chemical Engineers
¿  American National Standards Institute
¿  American Petroleum Institute
¿  American Society for Testing and Materials
¿  American Society of Mechanical Engineers
¿  American Society of Nondestructive Testing
¿  Compressed Gas Association
¿  Heat Exchanger Institute
¿  Hydraulic Institute
¿  Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers
¿  Instrument Society of America
¿  Materials Technology Institute
¿  National Association of Corrosion Engineers
¿  National Board Inspection Code
¿  National Fire Protection Association
¿  Technical Association of the Pulp and Paper Industry
¿  Underwriters Laboratories
¿  U.S. Code of Federal Regulations

  Sources in addition to those listed above may be appropriate depending on the type of process equipment and equipment service. These references establish the basis for the inspection and testing frequency for each equipment item as well as the inspection and testing methods to be employed [40 CFR 68.56(d)].  

  Additional data to be considered in the development of inspection and testing requirements and their frequency include the recommendations of the equipment manufacturer and plant operating experience [40 CFR 68.56(d)]. Sources of plant-specific and equipment-specific data include the equipment manufacturer operation and maintenance manuals, plant operating history, equipment specifications, records of equipment failure and downtime, operator logs, maintenance logs, inspection logs, and interviews with knowledgeable engineering, inspection, maintenance, and operatio

ns personnel. Plant operating experience may be used to justify deviations from the inspection and testing requirements outlined in the applicable codes and standards. Specifically, plant operating experience may be used as the basis to justify more or less stringent inspection and testing requirements, as appropriate.  

  The inspection and testing schedule will document each inspection and test conducted, the date conducted, name of the person who performed the inspection or test, the serial number or other identifier of the equipment on which the inspection or test was performed, a description of the inspection or test performed, and the results of the inspection or test [40 CFR 68.56(a)].  

  Zinus USA Inc. will provide general awareness training on the hazards of the process provided to all site employees and contractors at least every three years or more often if necessary. Zinus employees working in the TDI storage and handling area are trained in all applicable maintenance activities, including the hazards of the process, in how to avoid or correct unsafe conditions, and in the procedures applicable to the employee's job tasks [40 CFR 68.56(b)]. 

  Contractor personnel must provide Zinus USA Inc. with documentation confirming that each contract employee possesses the necessary skills, knowledge, and qualifications or certification to perform the assigned tasks (i.e. inspector certifications, etc.) [40 CFR 68.56(c)]. Contractor personnel must also demonstrate an understanding of the plant's safe work practices and contractor orientation information.  

  At Zinus USA Inc., a compliance audit must be completed at least every three years and include verification that the procedures and practices that have been developed to comply with the RMP regulations are adequate and are being followed [40 CFR 68.58(a)]. The compliance audit will be conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process [40 CFR 68.58(b)], and this person should be impartia

l toward those facility or area being audited. Zinus USA Inc will develop a report of the findings [40 CFR 68.58(c] and must certify the audit report.  An employer is generally a member of management at the facility that is not exposed to the hazard and should also be at a level that is capable of committing the necessary resources to correct any deficiencies discovered in the audit. Zinus USA Inc shall promptly determine and document an appropriate response to each of the findings of the compliance audit and document that the deficiencies have been corrected [40 CFR 68.58(d)].  

  Compliance audit documentation, including forms and the most recent audit will be used to complete the audit report. At least one individual knowledgeable of the process will use an applicable compliance audit checklist.  A compliance audit certification page will be the place where the audit is certified by Zinus USA Inc. and attached to the compliance audit checklist after completion of the compliance audit. The compliance audit record of findings will be developed from the information gathered during the compliance audit. This information, or a site action tracking system that has been populated with the compliance audit record of findings information, will be periodically reviewed and updated to ensure that an appropriate response is documented for each finding, and that each deficiency is corrected. When all items have been appropriately addressed, the completed compliance audit record of findings is retained with the compliance audit. The two most recent compliance audit reports and documentation of the completion of their record of findings are to be retained, but Zinus USA Inc is not required to maintain audit reports that are more than 5 years old [40 CFR 68.58(e)].  

5. Five-year Accident History

  Since the McDonough facility is a new construction, it has had zero RMP reportable incidents in the previous five years. The following requirements apply if Zinus USA Inc. ha

facility. Per 29 CFR 1910.34(a), workplaces in general industry, except mobile workplaces such as vehicles and vessels, are required to develop an emergency action plan based on the requirements in 29 CFR 1910.38. The Zinus USA Inc. facility has developed a written emergency action plan (EAP) based on the requirements in 29 CFR 1910.38 as a best practice.

  As a non-responding stationary source, Zinus USA Inc. will coordinate with the Local emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) for the McDonough facility to be included in the community emergency response plan [40 CFR 68.90(b)(1)]. Zinus USA Inc. is required to coordinate response needs with local emergency planning and response organizations to determine how the McDonough facility is addressed in the community Emergency Response Plan (ERP) and to ensure that local response organizations are aware of the regulated substances at the facility (i.e., TDI), their location and quantities, the risks presented by covered processes, and the resources and capabilities at the facility to respond to an accidental release of a regulated substance [40 CFR 68.93].

  Coordination shall occur at least annually, and more frequently if necessary, to address changes: At the Zinus USA Inc. McDonough facility; in the facility's Emergency Action Plan (EAP); and/or in the community ERP [40 CFR 68.93(a)]. Coordination shall include providing to the local emergency planning and response organizations: Zinus' USA Inc. EAP; updated emergency contact information; and other information necessary for developing and implementing the local emergency response plan [40 CFR 68.93(b)].

  Zinus USA Inc. must document coordination with local authorities, including: The names of individuals involved and their contact information (phone number, email address, and organizational affiliations); dates of coordination activities; and nature of coordination activities [40 CFR 68.93(c)].

  At least once each calendar year, Zinus USA Inc. is required

conduct an exercise of the stationary source's emergency response notification mechanisms [40 CFR 68.96(a)]. Zinus USA Inc. is required to maintain a written record of each notification exercise conducted over the last five years.

  In the event of a large fire at the facility (e.g., cannot be contained by a fire extinguisher, involves flammable chemicals, or jeopardizes personnel safety) person discovering fire should exit the facility in accordance with the exit routes and call 911 and the Zinus USA Inc. facility Emergency Response Team (ERT). [29 CFR 1910.38(c)(1)]. In the event of a release of TDI vapors which triggers the gas detection system alarm, TDI operations will be shut down and employees will exit the TDI bulk foam storage room and notify the Zinus USA Inc. facility ERT, who will determine whether McDonough facility evacuation is necessary, depending upon the nature of the release. If the release requires a response beyond the scope of routine maintenance, the ERT will call 911 in order to receive outside assistance from the McDonouogh Fire Department.

  In the event of a fire at the facility, all employees will evacuate through the nearest exit and travel to the designated safe locations as identified in the EAP. All employees are trained to assist other employees in a safe and orderly evacuation [29 CFR 1910.38(c)(2)] consistent with our current egress layout.  Note that there are no facility processes that would require continued operation during an emergency. If feasible, Zinus USA Inc. employees will trigger the emergency shutdown system of a process, if on the route, during evacuation [29 CFR 1910.38(c)(3)].

  All employees at the facility will account for each other during an emergency evacuation to determine if all persons (including contractors and visitors) have evacuated safely [29 CFR 1910.38(c)(4)].  A designated supervisor or operator will contact all other personnel that have evacuated the facility following the evacuation after

all personnel have arrived at a safe location.

  In case of an emergency injury or illness, the facility will alert the appropriate local Emergency Medical Services (EMS) as seen fit by the most experienced employee at the facility. Only those employees who have current First Aid or CPR Certification may perform medical duties in the event of an emergency if they are comfortable doing so [29 CFR 1910.38(c)(5)].

  When employees are integrated into the organization, information on the name or job title of every employee who may be contacted by employees as an emergency coordinator or who would like more information about the plan or an explanation of their duties under the plan will be available. If employees would like more information about the plan or an explanation of their duties under then plan, they may contact Eric Evans, EHS Manager, at (803) 530-4850 [29 CFR 1910.38(c)(6)].  
 
  The Zinus USA Inc. McDonough TDI tank loading pump is equipped with an emergency shutdown button at the truck unloading station. The inspection, maintenance, and testing requirements for the alarm systems are documented in the site's Maintenance Inspection and Testing plan [29 CFR 1910.38(d)]. Alarm systems include audible and visual employee alarms for both fires and high levels of TDI vapors in the TDI bulk storage room.

  A review of the emergency plan will be completed with the site employees initially, periodically, and whenever a change in the plan, including alarm systems or exits, occurs. The appropriate personnel will review this procedure with each employee covered by the plan when [29 CFR 1910.38(f)]:

¿   An employee is initially assigned to a job,
¿   The employee's responsibilities under the plan change, and
¿   The plan is changed.  

   Training as applicable for employees who assist in a safe and orderly evacuation of other employees in the event of an accidental release will be provided as part of the site training. As a best practice, Zinus perso

nnel and the McDonough Fire Department may coordinate fire/emergency training drills on an annual basis [29 CFR 1910.38(e)].

6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

  Our planned changes as a new facility prior to improve safety at the Zinus USA Inc. facility starts with building and growing relationships with our suppliers, the community, customers and new employees.  Continuing this approach since last August better enables us to comply with supplier related regulations of 40 CFR 68.56(c) for safe work practices on site, having a robust emergency response from our LEPC element at the McDonough Fire Department as well as our quick responder for follow on operations consistent with 40 CFR 68.93 (a & b) & 29 CFR 1910.120, and integrate our new employees with RMP TDI training considerations consistent with 40 CFR 68.170(g).  Once our new employees are integrated into the Zinus USA Inc. family, we intend to have bottom-up Environmental, Health and Safety Committees that will have added value as it pertains to our TDI room and Laaderberg foaming area to continuously improve the process. To identify potential future structural changes to improve safety many new companies in their infancy stage address these during a commissioning process to continuously improve, Zinus USA Inc. is no different.

  If you have any questions, concerns or feedback with our eRMP submittal for the Zinus USA Inc. facility, please contact Eric T. Evans, EHS Manager at eevans@zinus.com or (803) 530-4850.


Respectfully,

HB Sung
President
Zinus USA Inc.
